titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller Foundation records, Program and Policy, Health Sciences, SG 3.4
A Guide to the Rockefeller Foundation records, Program and Policy, Health Sciences, SG 3.4 FA1199

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-02-01 05:30:22 UTC.

did.unittitle: Rockefeller Foundation records, Program and Policy, Health Sciences, SG 3.4

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Foundation retains title, copyright and literary and intellectual property rights to the records, in so far as it holds them. Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: correspondence, memoranda, and organizational materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Scott Halstead is a world leader in research on dengue and other arthropod-borne viral infections. He has published over 400 scientific papers and book chapters on many areas of vaccine research and in international health development. In 1990, while with the Rockefeller Foundation, he co-founded the Children's Vaccine Initiative.
Born in India, then moved to White Plains in 1936. Scott Halstead graduated from Yale University with a B.A. in 1951 and from Columbia University with a M.D. in 1955.
From 1983-1995, at the Rockefeller Foundation, he served successively as Associate, Deputy and Acting Director of the Health Sciences Division.
